p: In addition, during viral infection, oxidative stress contributes to viral pathogenesis through stimulating inflammation, loss of immune function, and increased viral replication that may occur due to the activation of the nuclear factor kappa B (NF- κB) transcription pathway [ 24– 26]. Current evidence suggests that cytokine dysregulation—also called cytokine storm—contributes to severe disease caused by the pathogenic CoVs [ 27, 28]. The exact mechanisms are not clear yet, but research on influenza A virus shows that infection causes a rapid influx of inflammatory cells. This is followed by an increase in reactive oxygen species production and cytokine expression and release, which ultimately leads to acute lung injury [ 29]. In general, RNA viruses promote changes in the body's antioxidant defense system, affecting enzymes such as superoxide dismutase (SOD) and catalase (CAT), in addition to reducing the levels of antioxidant molecules such as ascorbic acid, carotenoids, and reduced glutathione (GSH) [ 30– 32]. Wu et al. reported that glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase- (an important antioxidant enzyme that produces NADPH) knockdown cells were more susceptible to infection by HCoV-229E than normal cells [ 33]. Interestingly, Ye and colleagues have reported that the inhibition of ROS production alleviates inflammation caused by influenza A virus infections [ 29].
